reviews.review_msg: Lectures are just reading off slides, and filled in slides are posted. Attendance for labs and lectures not mandatory, course content is doable

Lectures were difficult to understand but easy to learn on your own since the slides had lots of info on them. Labs and assignments were pretty hard but midterm and final exam were fairly straightforward.
His lectures you can't hear or understand anything, you are pretty much cooked for this class.

Prof just goes through slides as lecture, no need to go to them. Slides/ lectures themselves are very clear and structured. Labs are sometimes stressful as there was a 30% deduction for late submissions. Midterm and final are on paper and a little more challenging than labs.

Jie's lectures were very boring, and I can't hear him. However, he is very organized and knows how to run the course properly (unlike other programming profs). Considering that it's his first time teaching ensc 180, he's a solid prof.

Lectures are very boring, and it can be hard to understand him as he speaks rather quietly and with an accent
His slides are well made and informative and the weekly labs are great for improving understanding and helping study for tests

His lectures are kinda slow and monotone. His midterm makes no sense. His lectures slides though are goated. That being said, he mainly teaches upper level courses and this is the first time he's teaching a 100 level matlab course, so hopefully by the time you're reading this he has a bit more experience in that domain.
A really hardworking professor who tries his best to explain the best he could and gives instant replies via Canvas. Definitely one of the best professors on campus.

HE IS AWESOME! Clear, great great slides, his exams are super fair. Just attend class and ask as many questions as you want! Also, his italian accent makes it even better haha. Take as many classes as you can with him! Great marking schemes

awesome teacher! goes over difficult content in detail, answers questions quickly and fully on the discussion boards. assignments take time, but he is good at spreading it out! totally recommend Fabio!!!
smart and nice
Great professor who is willing to help and readily available to help!

Professor Campi marks very generously and is always compromising with the class. He let us decide how lecture hours would be spent and works VERY hard so that we could easily understand the subject matter. I like how he always says "I'm going to repeat what I just said to help you understand". So kind it's hard to imagine...

HE IS SUPER NICE! He tries his best to teach us and his TAs are very hard working. He also allows us to adapt code online for our assignment.He gives you fast respond on question and take any class with him.You will love engineering!
nice lecturer, very clear on what he expects you to know, truly cares about his students and treats them like they are someone important.
Fabio's a real cool dude and is really open to feedback from students.  You can tell that he genuinely cares about his students.
Fabio is the man

A great teacher. He's very helpful and knowledgeable. He's passionate about the subject and explains materials in detail but sometimes it's hard to follow. He encourages students not to use textbooks and search on Google instead.
Had an empty power point and typed in as he went. Very prepared for teaching!

Awful prof. We received an assignment that asked us to implement vectorization when he had not even explained the concept to us.   He expects us to have some knowledge of Matlab in an intro to Matlab course. He goes way too fast in lectures and puts emphasis on unimportant concepts that we barely use.

Dr. Scratchley really does mean well. He tries his best and is understanding of time conflicts other courses, and is willing to give extensions. However, he does have a habit of rambling, and often only reads off lecture slides. In his favour, he goes over assignments in detail (often spending too much time even) and is very open to questions.

Craig is one of the worst lecturers at SFU. He literally placed the textbook under the document camera and read aloud. This class was so frustratingly slow and I learned literally nothing despite doing really well. The labs were fun, but only because I was taking 3 courses and had the ridiculous amount of time needed to do well. Craig is the worst.

He is not so good at presenting lectures compare to other professors, but the assignment is interesting to me. Altought I cannot learn very much in his lecture, but from the assignment, I can get a lot of stuff. Do keep in mind that the assignments will be a bit tough.
I can proudly say I've been to a total of 3 lectures

Scratchley would make a good lab TA or highschool teacher, but a lecturer he is not. He is accessible and helpful on a person-by-person basis, but the lines after kectures and labs can have you waiting as much as 30mins. Lectures themselves are useless, as he literally opens the textbook and reads through and comments on it; class moves really slow

He's honestly a great prof. He stays an hour after lecture to help you with any questions you may have. Assignments were tough, but they came from the textbook, so if you read the book, you knew how to solve them. The students who are complaining, probably never came to class, read the book, or asked for help.

Very nice prof. However, the lectures were basically useless. He said he was learning Matlab with us, and he would get pretty flustered every time someone would ask a question. The assignments and quizzes were quite hard and required many things that we didn't learn in class. The final and midterm were open book and easy.

The whole semester I was lost. Lectures felt irrelevant and the assignments were not discussed during the lectures. Seems like assignments came out of nowhere, no explanation, no nothing. Very nice guy, but not so good professor (teaching skills a bit lacking).

He is one of the worst teach I have seen, bad teaching just read the book during the letter although it was the first semester he teaching ensc 180. Worse still, the quizzes are tough, not so relative with Matlab but more about economic, physics, math or chemistry. I learned only a little of Matlab programming. The assignments were interesting.

Made us pay around 40 for a website we used around 5 times. Doesn't follow any sort of syllabus. Doesn't even know matlab, admitted he would be "learning it with us" at the beginning of the course. Most disorganized professor I've ever seen, exams have no relation to course material. Scratchley is the man behind everything evil on this planet.

Assignments every 2wks, canvas quiz (assignment format, no time limit) every week, tophat questions are random. Tophat based on book but assignments based on internet. Exams are open book. Can't control the class and most people leave halfway but he's nice and helpful in person. Disorganized and NEW TO MATLAB. don't know why he teaches it
Craig is a nice person no doubt however all the classes are confused more important is materials are so hard this year midterm is so hard comparing to last year.

The only thing Nimal was good for was an excuse to nap. He reads everything off of his slides. The TAs are more useful than him for the assignments, so be sure to ask them lots of questions. It's impossible to avoid this prof either unless he stops teaching ENSC180 because it is only offered in the Spring, so good luck if he's your instructor.
